awd_abstract_narration:
This research project is aimed at solving mathematical problems that are not only significant as mathematics, but that have been suggested by problems arising in physics, quantum information theory and biology. The analysis of the equations governing physical  processes often requires a precise quantitative understanding of the relative sizes of various quantities involved in these processes, and this is provided by mathematical inequalities. An example familiar to the general public can be paraphrased as saying that ``entropy never decreases'' in physical processes;  the inequality in question says that the entropy at a later time is at least as large as the entropy at an earlier time. For more specific physical systems one can say much more, and the search for a better understanding of physical processes, and the evolution equations that govern them,  is in part a quest for new and more precise mathematical inequalities governing these processes. 

The connection between mathematical inequalities and physical processes runs both ways, so that in trying to prove  such an inequality, one may try to relate it to a simple and well understood evolution equation. This area of research has been fruitful not only in producing results that are of interest to a wider scientific community, but also in engaging the interest of Ph.D. students. The intellectual merit of the research is that it will produce not only significant new mathematics, but results that are relevant to the physical  sciences and engineering  as well. This applicability in other fields guarantee a broad impact of the work, which is further enhanced by the involvement of students, contributing to training of the next generation of researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many fundamental laws of physics are expressed in terms of inequalities, which state that a physical quantity is always larger than some given quantity. For instance, Heisenberg's uncertainty principle says that the uncertainty in position multiplied by the uncertainty in momentum is always at least as large as a certain multiple of Planck's constant. Another famous example is the Second Law of Thermodynamics -- entropy is always increasing, or what is the same thing, the rate of change of entropy  is always at least as large as zero.  


These are not isolated examples.  Although many laws of physics are  expressed in terms of equations, such as Schroedinger's equation, Boltzmann's equation, Maxwell's equations, etc.,  it is usually impossible to find explicit general solutions to these equations for systems of physical interest. Therefore, to understand what these equations are telling us, we need another approach. In many cases,  inequalities can give us the information we seek about the general solutions that we cannot explicitly write down.   For example, concerning the Boltzmann equation, entropy production inequalities,  which are a detailed refinement of the Second Law of Thermodynamics,  give information on how fast equilibrium must be approached by any solution of the Boltzmann equation. In general, inequalities are the sources of much of the information we have about general solutions of the equations describing the dynamics of physical systems, and the more refined these inequalities are, the more information we have.  The focus of this research project has been to develop new  inequalities and, as well, to further refine some known  inequalities and then to apply these results to better understand the behavior of physical systems.


  The branch of mathematics that deals with proving  inequalities is known as the Calculus of Variations. Progress in enlarging the family of known functional inequalities leads directly to a better understanding of the dynamics of physical systems, and conversely, consideration of physical questions often suggests a mathematical inequality. Sometimes it even suggests a strategy for a mathematical proof, and this brings together  two topics named in the title of the project: dynamics and variational problems.  The importance of this endeavor for better understanding the dynamics of physical systems is the basis of the intellectual merit of the research in this project which was devoted to enlarging the family of functional inequalities relevant to the understanding of the dynamics of various physical systems, and especial quantum systems.  The project was very successful in this regard, and has resulted in 14 publications in peer-reviewed academic journals, and not only mathematics journals, but also physics journals and in one case, and electrical engineering journal. Some of this work is already having a significant impact.  One paper by the PI and  his collaborator Jan Maas on an entropic description of quantum irreversible processes, though published only in 2020, three years later has 57 citations on Google Scholar.  All of this speaks to the broader impact of the research, which while the results obtained are a substantial contribution to pure mathematics, they are likely to be widely applied outside the core discipline of mathematics. Further broader impact of the project lies in the fact that 4 Rutgers graduate students were involved in the research and were partially supported by the project. Two of these, one a women, have already defended their PhD theses, and the others are expected to do so in due course. The research also directly informs the teaching of the PI in graduate courses naturally, but also in undergraduate courses, giving many Rutgers students a better understanding of what is happening in some current areas of scientific research.
